description.narrative: Output 5.1 A social movement created to drive the public action that accelerates the realization of the fundamental rights of children in Uganda, especially the most deprived, which contributes to Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Child Health, Child Poverty / Public Finance For Children, Child Protection â€“ General, Cross-Sectoral Communication For Development, Cross-Sectoral Monitoring, Data And Situation Analyses, Economic And Social Policy General, Education â€“ General, Environmental Sustainability, Evaluation And Research, Health â€“ General, Hiv Prevention, Hiv â€“ General, Immunization, Nutrition â€“ General, Other Cross-Sectoral Programme Areas, Policy Advocacy â€“ Urban, Civil Society, Parliament, Environment, Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition, Public Finance And Local Governance, Social Protection, Social Protection And Child Poverty, Treatment And Care Of Children Living With Hiv, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition, Wash â€“ General. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: 5. Innovative and participatory approaches and partnerships that increase public awareness and understanding of child rights in Uganda, create a social movement to position children on the national development agenda and promote positive individual behavior and social change

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 5.1 A social movement created to drive the public action that accelerates the realization of the fundamental rights ofchildren in Uganda, especially the most deprived

description.narrative: In 2020, the Public Advocacy team advocated for children’s rights by highlighting UNICEF programmes through the lens of beneficiaries. While the COVID-19 pandemic initially hampered content collection, it thereafter facilitated a refocus on critical issues like coping mechanisms for children, continued health service delivery and home learning. This realignment enabled UNICEF to reach new audiences, with an online engagement of more than 35 million people, five times higher than in 2019, and a traditional media reach of 42 million people. | Status:Met | As-of Date:13/01/2021
